etymologies: late 18th century: from French tolérant, present participle of tolérer, from Latin tolerare (see tolerate). Compare with earlier intolerant

definitions: showing willingness to allow the existence of opinions or behavior that one does not necessarily agree with

examples.text: we must be tolerant of others
a more tolerant attitude toward other religions

shortDefinitions: showing willingness to allow existence of opinions or behaviour that one does not necessarily agree with

definitions: (of a plant, animal, or machine) able to endure specified conditions or treatment

examples.text: rye is reasonably tolerant of drought

shortDefinitions: (of plant, animal, or machine) able to endure specified conditions or treatment
